text:
i had been facing slow download speeds from s3 for downloading drp files. aria2c enabled me to download it faster  (40KBPS->500KBPS) :slightly_smiling_face:
```
aria2c --enable-rpc=true --rpc-listen-all=true --continue=true --max-concurrent-downloads=10 --max-connection-per-server=16 --max-tries=0 --split=16 --stream-piece-selector=geom --enable-http-pipelining=true <https://github.com/digitalrebar/provision/releases/download/tip/dr-provision.zip>
```
<@U9DAYGSRL> nice!  I've used Aria for accelerating Ubuntu based mirror downloads, not for S3 buckets - didn't know it could do that.
yes, its a bit unknown. I had to reinstall drp in my laptop. and it helped me alot! sucks to see slow download speeds :slightly_smiling_face:
....and "slow speeds w/ S3" .... business as usual ... :slightly_smiling_face:

I'll take a look to see if we can add that in to our installer shell script - we do try hard to keep the requirements for the installer to bare minimums - so I'll probably wrap the download pieces with a check to see if it's available, and use if is - otherwise stick to the standard method
great !
can we do something similar for uploading bootenvs ?
since bootenvs are as well downloaded from s3 as well ?
<@U6QFVRJNB>

that would require a fair bit more change to handle - since that's all done in Golang currently - if there are any parallel Go lang based download libraries - we'd be willing to take a look at that - but as a rule we don't fork/exec to external processes
speeds are better via golang than it were via plain curl
you can use Aria to download the BootEnv ISO on to your DRP Endpoint (assuming it has outbound internet access) - and then move the ISO in to the `tftpboot/isos/` directory
oh ok
so in essence - you can do use Aria for your ISO bootenv downloads
let me try that
you do have to make sure that the ISO filename you move in to place matches the BootEnv expected ISO filename
and (of course) the `sha256sum` needs to match
ok! ll update... downloading
<@UA35R3W6L> has joined the channel
<@UA35Z8MJL> has joined the channel
<@UA35R3W6L> $Welcome
Digital Rebar welcome information is here > <http://rebar.digital/community/welcome.html>
<@UA35Z8MJL>, also $welcome :slightly_smiling_face:
Digital Rebar welcome information is here > <http://rebar.digital/community/welcome.html>

<!here> - we hope to see all of you online tomorrow at our V015 Meetup at 11:00 am PST - check out the Meetup pages for more details:
<https://www.meetup.com/digitalrebar/events/lchdhpyxgbnb/>

text: welp, I’m back… :wave:
It seems that Canonical’s MAAS is more for driving racks of bare metal as if they were cloud instances (kind of like Packet?)
It assumes continued contact and control over the nodes
Isn’t really for “deploy and forget” which is what I’m after
Welcome back Will!
And (surprisingly) it has no support for different partitioning schemes other than what they give you
Thanks Rob :grinning:
So I do like the curtin install speed — that’s much better than a preseed install
The DRP “immutable image” deploy is based on that, yes?
